instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: 820-000165 no power
threads.message:
So this was originally water damaged macbook air. changed <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and put it though ultrasonic cleaner. afterward computer was working fine, and passed asd. It sat in my shop for 89 days (i only hold them for 90). Went to show customer and now does power up.


Orarge light
no fan spin
pp3v42 - 3.42
ppbus - 8.58
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 0

what line is the the vcore?

threads.title: 820-000165 no power
threads.message: If you don’t have S5 rails you won’t have VCore. What is the resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>? Is <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: 820-000165 no power
threads.message:
I don't know what that means. 2.828 what?

Is <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> present? What voltage?

threads.title: 820-000165 no power
threads.message: If you mean 2.82 volts then that would at least indicate a problem around <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and the clock circuit as it needs to be 3.3. Also yes as Louis asked is G2 EN present?

threads.title: 820-000165 no power
threads.message:
okay replaced <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> now have 3.322v
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.420v

Edit: have fan spin now (its on max) but no chime.

I'm not sure if this is vcore but

<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL> - is 1.808

I have no light on usb mouse.

threads.title: 820-000165 no power
threads.message: Brain dead, could be water damage around <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>, J6100, SMC...

threads.title: 820-000165 no power
threads.message: no corrsion on j6100.  should i replace <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> or smc first?

threads.title: 820-000165 no power
threads.message: Don't touch the SMC yet!! Kill JTAGs as your heart desires..

threads.title: 820-000165 no power
threads.message: Check termination resistors and traces from <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> to CPU and SMC. Also suspect would be crap under the SMC. It all depends on where the original corrosion damage was.
